headline: Easy Vegetable Pancakes Recipe
description: Savory pancakes stuffed to the gills with vegetables that'll satisfy both children and adults alike.
name: Easy Vegetable Pancakes Recipe

nutrition.servingSize: Serves 4 as a side or appetizer; makes 8 to 10 pancakes

recipeIngredient: 50 grams (1.75 ounces; 1/3 cup) whole wheat, rice, roasted rice, or chickpea flour (see note)
1/2 teaspoon (2g) Diamond Crystal kosher salt plus more for seasoning; if using table salt, use half as much by volume
1 large egg, straight from the fridge
1 tablespoon (17g) doubanjiang or other fermented bean paste (see note)
2/3 cup (160 ml) ice-cold water, plus more as needed (see note)
6 ounces salted green cabbage (about 1 1/4 cups; 168g from 1/4 head of cabbage) or kimchi, roughly chopped (see note)
1 small carrot (about 2 ounces; 60g), peeled and grated on large holes of box grater
1/2 cup (120ml) vegetable oil for frying, plus extra as needed

recipeInstructions.text: For the Dipping Sauce: Combine soy sauce, rice vinegar, and sesame oil in a small bowl and stir briefly to combine. Set aside.
For the Pancakes : In a large bowl, whisk together all-purpose flour, whole wheat flour (or other flour), 1/2 teaspoon of salt, and baking powder until well-combined, about 30 seconds. Set aside.

In a separate medium bowl, whisk together egg, doubanjiang (or other fermented bean paste), garlic, and water until mixture is homogeneous, about 1 minute. Add wet mixture to large mixing bowl with flour mixture and whisk together just until a smooth, loose batter forms; the consistency should be similar to pancake batter; it should flow easily off the whisk and puddle briefly on top of the batter in the bowl. Add additional ice-cold water as needed to achieve this consistency, taking care not to over-mix the batter.
Add salted cabbage (or kimchi), grated carrot, and sliced scallions to batter and, using flexible spatula, fold in vegetables gently until evenly incorporated.

Heat oil in 12-inch stainless steel, well-seasoned cast iron, or nonstick skillet over medium-high heat until shimmering. Using a large spoon, small ladle, or measuring cup, add batter in 3-tablespoon (1 1/2-ounce; 45ml) portions (you can make larger or smaller pancakes as desired) to hot oil. For thinner, crispier pancakes, press down on batter to flatten them out; for thicker, fluffier pancakes, leave batter undisturbed. Cook, swirling oil once or twice, until pancakes are golden brown and crispy on first side, 2 to 3 minutes. Flip pancakes and continue cooking, swirling oil once or twice, until second side is golden and crispy, 2 to 3 minutes more. Transfer pancakes to wire rack set in rimmed baking sheet or paper towel-lined plate and season with salt. Repeat process with remaining batter, adding more oil if pan becomes too dry. Serve pancakes hot with dipping sauce alongside.

review.reviewBody: Really can use just about any leftover or fresh veggie. quick, easy delicious. I have difficulty standing at a stove waiting for them to cook. I have learned hat I can make them in a cookie sheet and bake, like sheet pan pancakes. Made several times now. My favorite is green onions, like scallion pancakes.
Just tell you kids thet they can't have any grown up food, and see how fast they change their tune.

This was great! I had a bunch of leftovers - chicken, roasted carrots, green beans and cole slaw mix. I cooked the cabbage mix, added the chopped veggies and chicken and then followed the recipe. I used gochujang, and added Kim Chee. It wasn't too spicy but very flavorful. I repurposed a dipping sauce that included ginger, but to refill it I used the recipe as stated (some ginger and sesame seeds were left, flavoring the refill).

Great way to reuse leftovers!
@Furluge - miso paste is super handy to keep in the fridge and lasts quite awhile. I love to use it in marinades for a punch of flavor.

Thanks, this sounds interesting -- and timely, at least on this end. I've been messing around a lot with okonomiyaki in the past several weeks, and this appears to be a great natural progression.

I can also attest to the power of the pancake for "hiding" veggies. My son, who would most definitely turn his nose up at a pile of cabbage -- no matter how deliciously stir-fried -- will absolutely devour the stuff when packed into an okonomiyaki. This, despite the fact that it's pretty obviously cabbage, and not nearly as well seasoned in the pancake as it would be in a solo dish. I don't even remotely get his mindset, but nor do I really mind. It simply means that I have a perfectly valid excuse to regularly make and eat a lot of okonomiyaki myself.
